channel.title: Private Eye RSS
channel.description: The UK's number one best-selling news and current affairs magazine, edited by Ian Hislop

item.title: OUT NOW! Private Eye issue 1336
item.description: Find out whats in the latest edition of Private Eye. Selected highlights from the UK's number one best-selling news and current affairs magazine including our top stories, cartoons, the Eye crossword, Dumb Britain, Lookalikes, Colemanballs and much more. Plus added extras including our online shop for subscriptions offers, binders and back issues plus the eyePlayer, Covers Library, Blog and Classifieds.

item.title: From In The Back: Auditing the auditor-general
item.description: A REMARKABLE email from former HM Revenue & Customs boss Dave Hartnett to senior colleagues reveals a major cover-up by Amyas Morse, head of the National Audit Office and the man trusted by parliament to investigate allegations of wrongdoing in Whitehall. The email poses serious questions over Morse's suitability as auditor-general and Britain's principal public spending watchdog.

item.title: From Columnists: The dead Samaritans
item.description: ON 5 March, NHS chief executive Sir David "no accountability" Nicholson told the Commons health select committee that he always takes the concerns of NHS whistleblowers seriously and has always acted appropriately to investigate them when brought to his attention.

item.title: From News: Counsel of despair...
item.description: AS Vicky Pryce sits in the slammer she is brooding none too fondly on the conduct of her lawyers - in particular her leading counsel, Claire Montgomery QC.

item.title: From Media News: Lights, camera - redaction!
item.description: "THE BBC has accepted Nick Pollard's report and its findings. We have now published all of the background material for his report. We have nothing further to add."

item.title: From HP Sauce: Crossed lines on tax
item.description: MOBILE phone firm Lycamobile was the Tories' fourth largest donor in the latest quarterly figures from the Electoral Commission. How odd, then, given chancellor George Osborne's sudden interest in corporate tax avoidance, that its latest accounts, published at the end of February, show that it still doesn't pay UK corporation tax.

item.title: From Street Of Shame: Those secret talks in full...
item.description: THE Media Standards Trust is none too happy with the secret negotiations between the Street of Shame and Downing Street over press regulation.

item.title: From In The Back: A familiar ritual
item.description: TWO DAYS after a report was published on the extensive allegations of sexual abuse against Jimmy Savile, the Sunday Express carried a front-page splash, "SAVILE WAS PART OF SATANIC RING", and an inside page story starring none other than Valerie Sinason (Eyes passim), a Harley Street psychotherapist who has been one of the UK's main proponents of a belief in Satanic ritual abuse.

item.title: From Media News: The Prefect storm
item.description: INCOMING BBC director-general Lord Hall has asserted his Birtist ascendancy with a new management team, but the spectre of Jimmy Savile still stalks the land - fortunately for the "Head Prefect", who found Nick Pollard's report on the scandal a useful justification for some, er, pollarding to the uppermost branches of the ailing ash that is the BBC.

item.title: From News: Very fuel-ish behaviour
item.description: MORE information emerges on the cash-strapped coalition's foolhardy proposal to sell off the strategically critical Government Pipeline and Storage System (GPSS - see Eye 1332). It suggests that not only is the sale potentially disastrous for security of oil supplies to key military air bases and civilian airports, but it probably makes no financial sense either.
